page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 100: Line 100:
===31 January===
===31 January===
  +
[[File:EAF Mi-17 over Cairo.jpg|thumb|An Egyptian Air Force [[Mi-17]] circling over Tahrir Square]]
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
â
[[File:EAF Mi-17 over Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|An Egyptian Air Force [[Mi-17]] circling over Tahrir Square]]
 
Hundreds of thousands continued to protest in Egyptian cities, including 250,000 protesters in Cairo alone.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/watch_now|title=Live Stream â Watch Now|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/30/live-blog-311-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 31/1 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> A protester was shot dead in [[Abu Simbel]] and extra troops were moved to guard the [[Suez Canal]].<ref name="aljazeera1" /> For the first time during protests, there were pro-Mubarak protests of at least 1,000 people, mostly from neighbourhood watch groups.<!--from tv--> Mohamed ElBaradei again joined thousands of protesters in Tahrir Square. He told the crowd, "What we have begun cannot go back", referring to the previous days of anti-government protests. The [[National Association for Change]], an [[umbrella group]] that contains several opposition movements including the Muslim Brotherhood and pro-democracy groups, chose ElBaradei to negotiate with Mubarak.
Hundreds of thousands continued to protest in Egyptian cities, including 250,000 protesters in Cairo alone.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/watch_now|title=Live Stream â Watch Now|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/30/live-blog-311-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 31/1 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> A protester was shot dead in [[Abu Simbel]] and extra troops were moved to guard the [[Suez Canal]].<ref name="aljazeera1" /> For the first time during protests, there were pro-Mubarak protests of at least 1,000 people, mostly from neighbourhood watch groups.<!--from tv--> Mohamed ElBaradei again joined thousands of protesters in Tahrir Square. He told the crowd, "What we have begun cannot go back", referring to the previous days of anti-government protests. The [[National Association for Change]], an [[umbrella group]] that contains several opposition movements including the Muslim Brotherhood and pro-democracy groups, chose ElBaradei to negotiate with Mubarak.
